item.itunes:subtitle: Ephesians 6:1-4
item.description:

Graham looks at the advice Paul gives to Parents and Children about their relationships and quotes from a Tim Keller talk. Children should.....
  1. Value their parents (cultural appropriate)
  2. Don;t assume your parents can't change
  3. Show them what you've learned from them
  4. Forgive them
  5. Leave them
Parents should

  2. Keep suitable boundaries
  3. Bring them up in the Lord

Graham explains how easy it is to forget all the blessings we have, especially ongoing blessings. We take it for granted and lose grip on reality. The solution: thankfulness. It is a discipline to pause and say thanks. A model for giving thanks Spiritual thank you for jesus, thank you Physical thank you for me, health, who we are Emotional thank you I can experience things Intellectual thank you for intellectual blessings Material thank you for clothes, money. roof etc Relational thank you for people you put around me

item.title: Heresies : Valentinism : Ralph Kemp : 18Sep16
item.itunes:subtitle: Colossians 2:6-12
item.description:
After the success of this 'mini-series' last year, we bring you: "Early Christian Heresies Part II"! By looking at what our faith ISN'T, we gain a deeper understanding of what our faith IS. Join us as we look at Ebionitim, Docetism and Valentinism (and try to pronounce them, if you can...)
Ralph explains about the divide between the physical and spiritual world that Valentinism promotes and why he was wrong. We are not "Spirits in a material world" - and all the information we need for our salvation is clearly written for us in the Bible.

item.title: Heresies : Docetism : Veronica Johnston : 11Sep16
item.itunes:subtitle: Colossians 1:15-23
item.description:
After the success of this 'mini-series' last year, we bring you: "Early Christian Heresies Part II"! By looking at what our faith ISN'T, we gain a deeper understanding of what our faith IS. Join us as we look at Ebionitim, Docetism and Valentinism (and try to pronounce them, if you can...)

item.title: Heresies : Ebionitism : Graham Shaw : 4Sep16
item.itunes:subtitle: Mark 2:1-12
item.description:
After the success of this 'mini-series' last year, we bring you: "Early Christian Heresies Part II"! By looking at what our faith ISN'T, we gain a deeper understanding of what our faith IS. Join us as we look at Ebionitim, Docetism and Valentinism (and try to pronounce them, if you can...)
Graham explains the early heresy of Ebionitism and its lessons for us as Christians today.
1. Importance of believing and knowing that Jesus was the son of God. 2. Being careful of the "back to Judaism" movement. Some good but danger of losing sight of Jesus. 3. Everybody comes to Jesus wearing their own set of glasses. Everyone experiences a paradigm shift.

item.title: Peter : Peter Called : Graham Shaw : 29May16
item.itunes:subtitle: Luke 5:1-11
item.description:
Peter was a down to earth, 'say it as it is' normal bloke - an unschooled fisherman from Galilee. However, his life was forever changed through meeting Jesus. Journey with us as we look at his inspired highs, and disastrous lows as he lived, like us, as a disciple of Jesus.
Graham opens up the sermon series for us.

item.title: Ruth - Loving in a world of broken relationships : The Geneaology : Ralph Kemp : 13Mar16
item.itunes:subtitle: Ruth 4:13-22
item.description: The book of Ruth is a story of love shining through in the context of brokenness. In today's broken world, what does it mean for us to live 'loving lives'? Ralph calls this “Sex, Family and the Future”. Naomi in the face of tragedy acted sacrificially. Ruth did not take the easy way but chose to follow. When all seemed hopeless. Boaz was compassionate on a woman from another land. Stepped up to his responsibility as a redeemer. The baby became forefather of David, and again Jesus. Bethlehem plays it part again in the future. Consequential significance of these acts of love.

item.title: The Kingdom of Heaven : Weeds : Veronica Johnson : 10Jan16
item.itunes:subtitle: Matthew 13:24-43
item.description:

item.title: This Is Not Your Home : Living Good Lives : Citizens : Graham Shaw : 08Feb15
item.itunes:subtitle: 1 Peter 2:11-17
item.description:
You’re chosen aliens, part of a real but unseen kingdom. Don’t conform to this world, but live holy lives within it, loving one another. The world will persecute you, and falsely accuse you, but confound them by continuing to bless them. Your gentleness and respect will win some over. Keep the perspective of the coming judgement and your future glory, keeping your eyes fixed on Jesus, who won us our salvation and is our example in everything.
Typical responses to society
  1. Condemn. We'll have nothing to do it.
  2. Consume it.
  3. Copy. They do this, so we do the same.
  4. Critique. I like those bits but not those bits.
  5. Culture creators. Witnesses within the culture we are set. Proactive.
'Culture making' by Andy Crouch

item.description:
Mark

Mark 14:12-26

Become immersed in the most beautiful story in the world as we travel through the gospel of Mark.

Christianity is the only faith where we have a god who knows what it is like to experience suffering. Jesus provides a model of how we can cope. 1. Remembers who god is. 2. Telling him the situation. 3. I will leave it in your hands. Jesus does not face death in the way of conventional heros. Jesus is more real. Later day martyrs seem more confident. Whats the difference? Those Christians had their lives restored while Jesus was facing brokenness. Jesus had a near view of the furnace of wrath. Necessary that he had a full appreciation of his free choice. In order for us to find restoration Jesus had to be ripped apart.

item.title: Elijah : Who was Elijah? : Graham Shaw : 09Jun13
item.itunes:subtitle: Part 1 of 8
item.description:
Who was Elijah and what did he do?

Discover the story of Elijah's ministry as we spend 8 weeks going through the life of this Old Testament prophet.

Elijah came from nowhere, we know nothing about him until he told the King that there would be no rain. At that time Baal was worshipped and was the God of Rain. It’s like taking on Nadal on clay. It was his turf. He spoke truth in a difficult situations.

How can we learn? Never think who or what you are is an accident. Ask “where has god put me now so that i can serve him?” Why has God put you in the context you are in?

If you are not playing your role God will raise up someone else....

If we are blessed in any way we need to ask why we have been blessed and how can we be a blessing to others. God is in the business of raising people up in every situation.
